skos.definition: Serum potassium concentration below 3.5 mEq/L, commonly caused by GI or renal losses, which can cause muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and paralysis.
skos.scopeNote: Most common electrolyte abnormality; frequently coexists with hypomagnesemia

content.title: Hypokalemia
content.summary: Hypokalemia (K+ <3.5 mEq/L) is very common, most often from GI losses (vomiting, diarrhea) or diuretics. It causes characteristic ECG changes (U waves, flattened T waves), muscle weakness, and can be life-threatening when severe. Coexisting hypomagnesemia must be corrected for potassium repletion to be effective.
key_points: Common causes: GI losses (diarrhea, vomiting) and diuretics
ECG changes: flattened T waves, U waves, ST depression, prolonged QT
Refractory hypokalemia often indicates concurrent hypomagnesemia - check and replace Mg first
Urine K+ >20 mEq/L indicates renal wasting; <20 mEq/L indicates extrarenal losses
Oral replacement preferred; IV KCl at maximum 10-20 mEq/hr peripherally
Potassium shifts into cells with alkalosis, insulin, beta-agonists
Can cause ileus, rhabdomyolysis, and respiratory muscle weakness
content.statement: Hypokalemia results from decreased intake (rare alone), increased losses (GI or renal), or transcellular shift. The approach involves identifying the source of loss using clinical history and urine potassium, addressing underlying causes, and replacing potassium while monitoring for complications.

explanation.intuition: Potassium is critical for maintaining the resting membrane potential of muscles and nerves. When potassium is low, cells become hyperpolarized (more negative inside), making it harder to fire action potentials. This manifests as weakness, decreased reflexes, and cardiac conduction abnormalities. The heart is particularly sensitive because of its dependence on proper K+ gradients for repolarization.
explanation.key_insight: The urine potassium helps identify the source: if kidneys are working properly and the patient is hypokalemic, they should be conserving potassium (urine K+ <20 mEq/L). If urine K+ is high despite hypokalemia, there's a renal wasting problem (diuretics, hyperaldosteronism, RTA). Always check magnesium - it's required for potassium repletion to work.
explanation.technical_details: Potassium handling: 90% of K+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and loop of Henle. Secretion in the collecting duct (via ROMK and BK channels) is regulated by aldosterone, distal delivery of Na+, urine flow rate, and plasma K+. Alkalosis causes K+/H+ shift; for every 0.1 increase in pH, K+ falls ~0.6 mEq/L. Magnesium is required for Na+/K+-ATPase function; without it, potassium replacement is ineffective.

definitions_glossary.U_wave: Low-amplitude wave after T wave on ECG; characteristic of hypokalemia
definitions_glossary.TTKG: Transtubular potassium gradient - estimates collecting duct K+ secretion
definitions_glossary.primary_aldosteronism: Excess aldosterone causing hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis
definitions_glossary.Bartter_syndrome: Genetic defect mimicking loop diuretic effect; causes hypokalemia and alkalosis
definitions_glossary.Gitelman_syndrome: Genetic defect mimicking thiazide effect; milder than Bartter syndrome
definitions_glossary.renal_tubular_acidosis: RTA - types 1 and 2 cause hypokalemia; type 4 causes hyperkalemia
definitions_glossary.diuretic_induced: Loop and thiazide diuretics increase renal K+ losses via increased distal delivery
definitions_glossary.transcellular_shift: K+ moves into cells with alkalosis, insulin, beta-agonists, refeeding
definitions_glossary.aldosterone: Mineralocorticoid increasing K+ secretion and Na+ reabsorption in collecting duct
definitions_glossary.ROMK_channel: Renal outer medullary K+ channel; mediates K+ secretion in collecting duct
definitions_glossary.hypomagnesemia: Low magnesium frequently coexists; must correct for K+ repletion to be effective
definitions_glossary.potassium_chloride: KCl - preferred oral supplement; provides chloride to correct alkalosis
definitions_glossary.spot_urine_potassium: Used to differentiate renal (>20 mEq/L) from extrarenal (<20 mEq/L) losses
definitions_glossary.metabolic_alkalosis: Common with vomiting; causes and exacerbates hypokalemia

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hypokalemia develops from inadequate intake, transcellular shift, or increased losses. Total body potassium is ~3500 mEq; only 2% is extracellular, so small changes in serum K+ reflect large total body deficits.

gi_losses: Vomiting (renal K+ loss due to metabolic alkalosis and volume contraction)
etiology.decreased_intake: Rarely sole cause; usually contributes with other factors

signs: Paralysis (severe - ascending, may affect respiratory muscles)
ecg_changes: Arrhythmias (PACs, PVCs, atrial fibrillation, torsades de pointes)

urine_studies.spot_urine_K: Indicates source: <20 mEq/L (extrarenal loss), >20 mEq/L (renal loss)
urine_studies.TTKG: >4 in hypokalemia indicates inappropriate renal K+ secretion

oral_replacement.indication: Mild-moderate hypokalemia without ECG changes or symptoms
oral_replacement.formulations: KCl tablets, liquid, powder; K-citrate if acidotic

iv_replacement.indication: Severe hypokalemia, ECG changes, unable to take oral
iv_replacement.rate: Peripheral: 10 mEq/hr maximum (central line: up to 20 mEq/hr)
iv_replacement.concentration: Peripheral: 40 mEq/L maximum; higher concentrations require central access
iv_replacement.monitoring: Continuous cardiac monitoring if K+ <3.0 or rapid infusion

correct_magnesium.rationale: Hypomagnesemia causes renal K+ wasting and must be corrected first
correct_magnesium.dose: IV magnesium sulfate 2-4 g or oral magnesium oxide

treat_underlying_cause: Treat hyperaldosteronism with spironolactone or surgery

prognosis.recovery: Excellent with appropriate replacement and treatment of underlying cause
prognosis.severe_complications: Respiratory paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias can be fatal if untreated

learning_objectives: List common causes of hypokalemia by mechanism
Interpret spot urine potassium to differentiate renal from extrarenal losses
Recognize ECG changes associated with hypokalemia
Explain why hypomagnesemia must be corrected for potassium repletion to be effective
Calculate appropriate potassium replacement and safe IV infusion rates
Describe the relationship between acid-base status and potassium distribution
clinical_pearls: Refractory hypokalemia = check magnesium; it must be corrected first
Vomiting causes hypokalemia primarily through renal losses (not gastric), due to metabolic alkalosis and aldosterone
U waves on ECG are specific for hypokalemia (or bradycardia)
For every 1 mEq/L drop in K+, expect ~200-400 mEq total body deficit
Oral replacement is safer and preferred; IV only for severe or symptomatic
Diuretic + diarrhea is a classic setup for severe hypokalemia

common_question_stems: Patient on thiazide with weakness and U waves on ECG
Young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and alkalosis
Diarrhea patient with K+ 2.8 and urine K+ 12
exam_tips: Low K+ + high urine K+ = renal wasting (diuretics, hyperaldosteronism)
Low K+ + low urine K+ = extrarenal (GI losses, shifts)
Always check Mg - refractory hypokalemia = hypomagnesemia

teaching_cases.scenario: 58-year-old woman on HCTZ for hypertension presents with weakness and palpitations. K+ 2.6, Mg 1.2, HCO3 30. ECG shows U waves.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Hypokalemia with ECG changes, concurrent hypomagnesemia and metabolic alkalosis
teaching_cases.management: IV magnesium first, then IV potassium, switch to potassium-sparing diuretic or add amiloride

citations.authors: Kardalas E, Paschou SA, Anagnostis P, et al.
citations.title: Hypokalemia: a clinical update

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on NEJM review and current clinical practice guidelines

sources.source: UpToDate: Clinical manifestations and treatment of hypokalemia
